trans-unit.source: Analyze flight delay data with Hadoop in HDInsight | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Analyze flight delay data with Hadoop in HDInsight | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use one Windows PowerShell script to provision an HDInsight cluster, run a Hive job, run a Sqoop job, and delete the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use one Windows PowerShell script to provision an HDInsight cluster, run a Hive job, run a Sqoop job, and delete the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Hive provides a means of running Hadoop MapReduce jobs through an SQL-like scripting language called *<linkText>HiveQL[hadoop-hiveql]</linkText><title></title>*, which can be applied towards summarizing, querying, and analyzing large volumes of data.
trans-unit.target: Hive provides a means of running Hadoop MapReduce jobs through an SQL-like scripting language called *<linkText>HiveQL[hadoop-hiveql]</linkText><title></title>*, which can be applied towards summarizing, querying, and analyzing large volumes of data.

trans-unit.source: One of the major benefits of Azure HDInsight is the separation of data storage and compute.
trans-unit.target: One of the major benefits of Azure HDInsight is the separation of data storage and compute.

trans-unit.source: HDInsight uses Azure Blob storage for data storage.
trans-unit.target: HDInsight uses Azure Blob storage for data storage.

trans-unit.source: A common MapReduce process can be broken into 3 parts:
trans-unit.target: A common MapReduce process can be broken into 3 parts:

trans-unit.source: Store data in Azure Blob storage. This can be a continuous process.
trans-unit.target: Store data in Azure Blob storage. This can be a continuous process.

trans-unit.source: For example, weather data, sensor data, web logs, and in this case, flight delay data are saved into Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: For example, weather data, sensor data, web logs, and in this case, flight delay data are saved into Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: Run jobs. When it is time to process the data, you run a Windows PowerShell script (or a client application) to provision an HDInsight cluster, run jobs, and delete the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Run jobs. When it is time to process the data, you run a Windows PowerShell script (or a client application) to provision an HDInsight cluster, run jobs, and delete the cluster.

trans-unit.source: The jobs save output data to Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: The jobs save output data to Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: The output data is retained even after the cluster is deleted.
trans-unit.target: The output data is retained even after the cluster is deleted.

trans-unit.source: This way, you pay for only what you have consumed.
trans-unit.target: This way, you pay for only what you have consumed.

trans-unit.source: Retrieve the output from Azure Blob storage, or in this tutorial, export the data to an Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: Retrieve the output from Azure Blob storage, or in this tutorial, export the data to an Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: The following diagram illustrates the scenario and the structure of this tutorial:
trans-unit.target: The following diagram illustrates the scenario and the structure of this tutorial:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>HDI.FlightDelays.flow</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>HDI.FlightDelays.flow</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Note: The numbers in the diagram correspond to the section titles.
trans-unit.target: Note: The numbers in the diagram correspond to the section titles.

trans-unit.source: The main portion of the tutorial shows you how to use one Windows PowerShell script to perform the following:
trans-unit.target: The main portion of the tutorial shows you how to use one Windows PowerShell script to perform the following:

trans-unit.source: Provision an HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: Provision an HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Run a Hive job on the cluster to calculate average delays at airports.
trans-unit.target: Run a Hive job on the cluster to calculate average delays at airports.

trans-unit.source: The flight delay data is stored in an Azure Blob storage account.
trans-unit.target: The flight delay data is stored in an Azure Blob storage account.

trans-unit.source: Run a Sqoop job to export the Hive job output to an Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: Run a Sqoop job to export the Hive job output to an Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: Delete the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: Delete the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: In the appendixes, you can find the instructions for uploading flight delay data, creating/uploading a Hive query string, and preparing the Azure SQL database for the Sqoop job.
trans-unit.target: In the appendixes, you can find the instructions for uploading flight delay data, creating/uploading a Hive query string, and preparing the Azure SQL database for the Sqoop job.

trans-unit.source: The steps in this document are specific to Windows-based HDInsight clusters.
trans-unit.target: The steps in this document are specific to Windows-based HDInsight clusters.

trans-unit.source: For steps that will work with a Linux-based cluster, see <linkText>Analyze flight delay data using Hive in HDInsight (Linux)</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For steps that will work with a Linux-based cluster, see <linkText>Analyze flight delay data using Hive in HDInsight (Linux)</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: Before you begin this tutorial, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin this tutorial, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Get Azure free trial</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Get Azure free trial</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: A workstation with Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: A workstation with Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Install and use Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Install and use Azure PowerShell</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Understand HDInsight storage
trans-unit.target: Understand HDInsight storage

trans-unit.source: Hadoop clusters in HDInsight use Azure Blob storage for data storage.
trans-unit.target: Hadoop clusters in HDInsight use Azure Blob storage for data storage.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Use Azure Blob storage with HDInsight[hdinsight-storage]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Use Azure Blob storage with HDInsight[hdinsight-storage]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When you provision an HDInsight cluster, a Blob storage container of an Azure Storage account is designated as the default file system, just like in Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS).
trans-unit.target: When you provision an HDInsight cluster, a Blob storage container of an Azure Storage account is designated as the default file system, just like in Hadoop Distributed File System (HDFS).

trans-unit.source: This Storage account is referred to as the default Storage account, and the Blob container is referred to as the default Blob container or default container.
trans-unit.target: This Storage account is referred to as the default Storage account, and the Blob container is referred to as the default Blob container or default container.

trans-unit.source: The default Storage account must be co-located in the same datacenter as the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: The default Storage account must be co-located in the same datacenter as the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Deleting an HDInsight cluster does not delete the default container or the default Storage account.
trans-unit.target: Deleting an HDInsight cluster does not delete the default container or the default Storage account.

trans-unit.source: In addition to the default Storage account, other Azure Storage accounts can be bound to an HDInsight cluster during the provisioning process.
trans-unit.target: In addition to the default Storage account, other Azure Storage accounts can be bound to an HDInsight cluster during the provisioning process.

trans-unit.source: The binding is to add the Storage account and Storage account key to the configuration file so the cluster can access those Storage accounts at run time.
trans-unit.target: The binding is to add the Storage account and Storage account key to the configuration file so the cluster can access those Storage accounts at run time.

trans-unit.source: For instructions on adding additional Storage accounts, see <linkText>Provision Hadoop clusters in HDInsight[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions on adding additional Storage accounts, see <linkText>Provision Hadoop clusters in HDInsight[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Blob storage syntax is:
trans-unit.target: The Azure Blob storage syntax is:

trans-unit.source: The Blob storage path is a virtual path.
trans-unit.target: The Blob storage path is a virtual path.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>Use Azure Blob storage with HDInsight[hdinsight-storage]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>Use Azure Blob storage with HDInsight[hdinsight-storage]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Files stored in the default container can be accessed from HDInsight by using any of the following URIs (using flightdelays.hql as an example):
trans-unit.target: Files stored in the default container can be accessed from HDInsight by using any of the following URIs (using flightdelays.hql as an example):

trans-unit.source: For accessing the file directly from the Storage account, the blob name for the file is:
trans-unit.target: For accessing the file directly from the Storage account, the blob name for the file is:

trans-unit.source: Notice there is no "/" in the front of the blob name.
trans-unit.target: Notice there is no "/" in the front of the blob name.

trans-unit.source: Files used in this tutorial
trans-unit.target: Files used in this tutorial

trans-unit.source: This tutorial uses the on-time performance of airline flight data from <linkText>Research and Innovative Technology Administration, Bureau of Transportation Statistics or RITA[rita-website]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial uses the on-time performance of airline flight data from <linkText>Research and Innovative Technology Administration, Bureau of Transportation Statistics or RITA[rita-website]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The data has been uploaded to an Azure Blob storage container with the Public Blob access permission.
trans-unit.target: The data has been uploaded to an Azure Blob storage container with the Public Blob access permission.

trans-unit.source: Because it is a public Blob container, you do not need to bind this Storage account to the HDInsight cluster running the Hive script.
trans-unit.target: Because it is a public Blob container, you do not need to bind this Storage account to the HDInsight cluster running the Hive script.

trans-unit.source: The HiveQL script is also uploaded to the same Blob container.
trans-unit.target: The HiveQL script is also uploaded to the same Blob container.

trans-unit.source: If you want to learn how to get/upload the data to your own Storage account, and how to create/upload the HiveQL script file, see <linkText>Appendix A</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Appendix B</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you want to learn how to get/upload the data to your own Storage account, and how to create/upload the HiveQL script file, see <linkText>Appendix A</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Appendix B</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The following table lists the files used in this tutorial:
trans-unit.target: The following table lists the files used in this tutorial:

trans-unit.source: Files
trans-unit.target: Files

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: wasb://flightdelay@hditutorialdata.blob.core.windows.net/flightdelays.hql
trans-unit.target: wasb://flightdelay@hditutorialdata.blob.core.windows.net/flightdelays.hql

trans-unit.source: The HiveQL script file used by the Hive job that you will run. This script has been uploaded to an Azure Blob storage account with the public access.
trans-unit.target: The HiveQL script file used by the Hive job that you will run. This script has been uploaded to an Azure Blob storage account with the public access.

trans-unit.source: Appendix B
trans-unit.target: Appendix B

trans-unit.source: has instructions on preparing and uploading this file to your own Azure Blob storage account.
trans-unit.target: has instructions on preparing and uploading this file to your own Azure Blob storage account.

trans-unit.source: wasb://flightdelay@hditutorialdata.blob.core.windows.net/2013Data
trans-unit.target: wasb://flightdelay@hditutorialdata.blob.core.windows.net/2013Data

trans-unit.source: Input data for the Hive job. The data has been uploaded to an Azure Blob storage account with the public access.
trans-unit.target: Input data for the Hive job. The data has been uploaded to an Azure Blob storage account with the public access.

trans-unit.source: Appendix A
trans-unit.target: Appendix A

trans-unit.source: has instructions on getting the data and uploading the data to your own Azure Blob storage account.
trans-unit.target: has instructions on getting the data and uploading the data to your own Azure Blob storage account.

trans-unit.source: \tutorials\flightdelays\output
trans-unit.target: \tutorials\flightdelays\output

trans-unit.source: The output path for the Hive job. The default container is used for storing the output data.
trans-unit.target: The output path for the Hive job. The default container is used for storing the output data.

trans-unit.source: \tutorials\flightdelays\jobstatus
trans-unit.target: \tutorials\flightdelays\jobstatus

trans-unit.source: The Hive job status folder on the default container.
trans-unit.target: The Hive job status folder on the default container.

trans-unit.source: Understand the Hive internal table and external table
trans-unit.target: Understand the Hive internal table and external table

trans-unit.source: There are a few things you need to know about the Hive internal table and external table:
trans-unit.target: There are a few things you need to know about the Hive internal table and external table:

trans-unit.source: The CREATE TABLE command creates an internal table.
trans-unit.target: The CREATE TABLE command creates an internal table.

trans-unit.source: The data file must be located in the default container.
trans-unit.target: The data file must be located in the default container.

trans-unit.source: The CREATE TABLE command moves the data file to the /hive/warehouse/ folder.
trans-unit.target: The CREATE TABLE command moves the data file to the /hive/warehouse/ folder.

trans-unit.source: The CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE command creates an external table.
trans-unit.target: The CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE command creates an external table.

trans-unit.source: The data file can be located outside the default container.
trans-unit.target: The data file can be located outside the default container.

trans-unit.source: The CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE command does not move the data file.
trans-unit.target: The CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE command does not move the data file.

trans-unit.source: The CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE command doesn't allow any folders in the LOCATION.
trans-unit.target: The CREATE EXTERNAL TABLE command doesn't allow any folders in the LOCATION.

trans-unit.source: This is the reason why the tutorial makes a copy of the sample.log file.
trans-unit.target: This is the reason why the tutorial makes a copy of the sample.log file.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>HDInsight: Hive Internal and External Tables Intro[cindygross-hive-tables]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>HDInsight: Hive Internal and External Tables Intro[cindygross-hive-tables]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: One of the HiveQL statements creates a Hive external table.
trans-unit.target: One of the HiveQL statements creates a Hive external table.

trans-unit.source: The Hive external table keeps the data file in the original location.
trans-unit.target: The Hive external table keeps the data file in the original location.

trans-unit.source: The Hive internal table moves the data file to hive\warehouse.
trans-unit.target: The Hive internal table moves the data file to hive\warehouse.

trans-unit.source: The Hive internal table requires the data file to be located in the default container.
trans-unit.target: The Hive internal table requires the data file to be located in the default container.

trans-unit.source: For data stored outside the default Blob container, you must use Hive external tables.
trans-unit.target: For data stored outside the default Blob container, you must use Hive external tables.

trans-unit.source: Hadoop MapReduce is batch processing.
trans-unit.target: Hadoop MapReduce is batch processing.

trans-unit.source: The most cost-effective way to run a Hive job is to provision a cluster for the job, and delete the job after the job is completed.
trans-unit.target: The most cost-effective way to run a Hive job is to provision a cluster for the job, and delete the job after the job is completed.

trans-unit.source: The following script covers the whole process.
trans-unit.target: The following script covers the whole process.

trans-unit.source: For more information on provisioning an HDInsight cluster and running Hive jobs, see <linkText>Provision Hadoop clusters in HDInsight[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Use Hive with HDInsight[hdinsight-use-hive]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on provisioning an HDInsight cluster and running Hive jobs, see <linkText>Provision Hadoop clusters in HDInsight[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title> and <linkText>Use Hive with HDInsight[hdinsight-use-hive]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To run the Hive queries by using Windows PowerShell
trans-unit.target: To run the Hive queries by using Windows PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure SQL database and the table for the Sqoop job output by using the instructions in <linkText>Appendix C</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure SQL database and the table for the Sqoop job output by using the instructions in <linkText>Appendix C</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Prepare the parameters:
trans-unit.target: Prepare the parameters:

trans-unit.source: Variable Name
trans-unit.target: Variable Name

trans-unit.source: Notes
trans-unit.target: Notes

trans-unit.source: $hdinsightClusterName
trans-unit.target: $hdinsightClusterName

trans-unit.source: The HDInsight cluster name. If the cluster doesn't exist, the script will create one with the name entered.
trans-unit.target: The HDInsight cluster name. If the cluster doesn't exist, the script will create one with the name entered.

trans-unit.source: $storageAccountName
trans-unit.target: $storageAccountName

trans-unit.source: The Azure Storage account that will be used as the default Storage account. This value is needed only when the script needs to create an HDInsight cluster. Leave it blank if you have specified an existing HDInsight cluster name for $hdinsightClusterName. If the Storage account with the value entered doesn't exist, the script will create one with the name.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Storage account that will be used as the default Storage account. This value is needed only when the script needs to create an HDInsight cluster. Leave it blank if you have specified an existing HDInsight cluster name for $hdinsightClusterName. If the Storage account with the value entered doesn't exist, the script will create one with the name.

trans-unit.source: $blobContainerName
trans-unit.target: $blobContainerName

trans-unit.source: The Blob container that will be used for the default file system. If you leave it blank, the $hdinsightClusterName value will be used.
trans-unit.target: The Blob container that will be used for the default file system. If you leave it blank, the $hdinsightClusterName value will be used.

trans-unit.source: $sqlDatabaseServerName
trans-unit.target: $sqlDatabaseServerName

trans-unit.source: The Azure SQL database server name. It has to be an existing server. See
trans-unit.target: The Azure SQL database server name. It has to be an existing server. See

trans-unit.source: Appendix C
trans-unit.target: Appendix C

trans-unit.source: for information about creating one.
trans-unit.target: for information about creating one.

trans-unit.source: $sqlDatabaseUsername
trans-unit.target: $sqlDatabaseUsername

trans-unit.source: The login name for the Azure SQL database server.
trans-unit.target: The login name for the Azure SQL database server.

trans-unit.source: $sqlDatabasePassword
trans-unit.target: $sqlDatabasePassword

trans-unit.source: The login password for the Azure SQL database server.
trans-unit.target: The login password for the Azure SQL database server.

trans-unit.source: $sqlDatabaseName
trans-unit.target: $sqlDatabaseName

trans-unit.source: The SQL database where Sqoop will export data to. The default name is HDISqoop. The table name for the Sqoop job output is AvgDelays.
trans-unit.target: The SQL database where Sqoop will export data to. The default name is HDISqoop. The table name for the Sqoop job output is AvgDelays.

trans-unit.source: Open Windows PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE).
trans-unit.target: Open Windows PowerShell Integrated Scripting Environment (ISE).

trans-unit.source: Copy and paste the following script into the script pane:
trans-unit.target: Copy and paste the following script into the script pane:

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to run the script.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to run the script.

trans-unit.source: The output shall be similar to:
trans-unit.target: The output shall be similar to:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>HDI.FlightDelays.RunHiveJob.output</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>HDI.FlightDelays.RunHiveJob.output</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Connect to your SQL database and see average flight delays by city in the AvgDelays table:
trans-unit.target: Connect to your SQL database and see average flight delays by city in the AvgDelays table:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>HDI.FlightDelays.AvgDelays.Dataset</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>HDI.FlightDelays.AvgDelays.Dataset</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Uploading the data file and the HiveQL script files (see <linkText>Appendix B</linkText><title></title>) requires some planning.
trans-unit.target: Uploading the data file and the HiveQL script files (see <linkText>Appendix B</linkText><title></title>) requires some planning.

trans-unit.source: The idea is to store the data files and the HiveQL file before provisioning an HDInsight cluster and running the Hive job.
trans-unit.target: The idea is to store the data files and the HiveQL file before provisioning an HDInsight cluster and running the Hive job.

trans-unit.source: You have two options:
trans-unit.target: You have two options:

trans-unit.source: Use the same Azure Storage account that will be used by the HDInsight cluster as the default file system. Because the HDInsight cluster will have the Storage account access key, you don't need to make any additional changes.
trans-unit.target: Use the same Azure Storage account that will be used by the HDInsight cluster as the default file system. Because the HDInsight cluster will have the Storage account access key, you don't need to make any additional changes.

trans-unit.source: Use a different Azure Storage account from the HDInsight cluster default file system. If this is the case, you must modify the provisioning part of the Windows PowerShell script found in Provision HDInsight cluster and run Hive/Sqoop jobs to include the Storage account as an additional Storage account.
trans-unit.target: Use a different Azure Storage account from the HDInsight cluster default file system. If this is the case, you must modify the provisioning part of the Windows PowerShell script found in Provision HDInsight cluster and run Hive/Sqoop jobs to include the Storage account as an additional Storage account.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see <linkText>Provision Hadoop clusters in HDInsight[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see <linkText>Provision Hadoop clusters in HDInsight[hdinsight-provision]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The HDInsight cluster then knows the access key for the Storage account.
trans-unit.target: The HDInsight cluster then knows the access key for the Storage account.

trans-unit.source: The Blob storage path for the data file is hard coded in the HiveQL script file.
trans-unit.target: The Blob storage path for the data file is hard coded in the HiveQL script file.

trans-unit.source: You must update it accordingly.
trans-unit.target: You must update it accordingly.

trans-unit.source: To download the flight data
trans-unit.target: To download the flight data

trans-unit.source: Browse to <linkText>Research and Innovative Technology Administration, Bureau of Transportation Statistics[rita-website]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Browse to <linkText>Research and Innovative Technology Administration, Bureau of Transportation Statistics[rita-website]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: On the page, select the following values:
trans-unit.target: On the page, select the following values:

trans-unit.source: Name
trans-unit.target: Name

trans-unit.source: Value
trans-unit.target: Value

trans-unit.source: Filter Year
trans-unit.target: Filter Year

trans-unit.source: Filter Period
trans-unit.target: Filter Period

trans-unit.source: January
trans-unit.target: January

trans-unit.source: Fields
trans-unit.target: Fields

trans-unit.source: *Year*, *FlightDate*, *UniqueCarrier*, *Carrier*, *FlightNum*, *OriginAirportID*, *Origin*, *OriginCityName*, *OriginState*, *DestAirportID*, *Dest*, *DestCityName*, *DestState*, *DepDelayMinutes*, *ArrDelay*, *ArrDelayMinutes*, *CarrierDelay*, *WeatherDelay*, *NASDelay*, *SecurityDelay*, *LateAircraftDelay* (clear all other fields)
trans-unit.target: *Year*, *FlightDate*, *UniqueCarrier*, *Carrier*, *FlightNum*, *OriginAirportID*, *Origin*, *OriginCityName*, *OriginState*, *DestAirportID*, *Dest*, *DestCityName*, *DestState*, *DepDelayMinutes*, *ArrDelay*, *ArrDelayMinutes*, *CarrierDelay*, *WeatherDelay*, *NASDelay*, *SecurityDelay*, *LateAircraftDelay* (clear all other fields)

trans-unit.source: Click Download.
trans-unit.target: Click Download.

trans-unit.source: Unzip the file to the C:\Tutorials\FlightDelays\Data folder.
trans-unit.target: Unzip the file to the C:\Tutorials\FlightDelays\Data folder.

trans-unit.source: Each file is a CSV file and is approximately 60GB in size.
trans-unit.target: Each file is a CSV file and is approximately 60GB in size.

trans-unit.source: Rename the file to the name of the month that it contains data for.
trans-unit.target: Rename the file to the name of the month that it contains data for.

trans-unit.source: For example, the file containing the January data would be named January.csv.
trans-unit.target: For example, the file containing the January data would be named January.csv.

trans-unit.source: Repeat steps 2 and 5 to download a file for each of the 12 months in 2013.
trans-unit.target: Repeat steps 2 and 5 to download a file for each of the 12 months in 2013.

trans-unit.source: You will need a minimum of one file to run the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: You will need a minimum of one file to run the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: To upload the flight delay data to Azure Blob storage
trans-unit.target: To upload the flight delay data to Azure Blob storage

trans-unit.source: Prepare the parameters:
trans-unit.target: Prepare the parameters:

trans-unit.source: Variable Name
trans-unit.target: Variable Name

trans-unit.source: Notes
trans-unit.target: Notes

trans-unit.source: $storageAccountName
trans-unit.target: $storageAccountName

trans-unit.source: The Azure Storage account where you want to upload the data to.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Storage account where you want to upload the data to.

trans-unit.source: $blobContainerName
trans-unit.target: $blobContainerName

trans-unit.source: The Blob container where you want to upload the data to.
trans-unit.target: The Blob container where you want to upload the data to.

trans-unit.source: Open Azure PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: Open Azure PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.source: Paste the following script into the script pane:
trans-unit.target: Paste the following script into the script pane:

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to run the script.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to run the script.

trans-unit.source: If you choose to use a different method for uploading the files, please make sure the file path is tutorials/flightdelays/data.
trans-unit.target: If you choose to use a different method for uploading the files, please make sure the file path is tutorials/flightdelays/data.

trans-unit.source: The syntax for accessing the files is:
trans-unit.target: The syntax for accessing the files is:

trans-unit.source: The path tutorials/flightdelays/data is the virtual folder you created when you uploaded the files.
trans-unit.target: The path tutorials/flightdelays/data is the virtual folder you created when you uploaded the files.

trans-unit.source: Verify that there are 12 files, one for each month.
trans-unit.target: Verify that there are 12 files, one for each month.

trans-unit.source: You must update the Hive query to read from the new location.
trans-unit.target: You must update the Hive query to read from the new location.

trans-unit.source: You must either configure the container access permission to be public or bind the Storage account to the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: You must either configure the container access permission to be public or bind the Storage account to the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the Hive query string will not be able to access the data files.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the Hive query string will not be able to access the data files.

trans-unit.source: Using Azure PowerShell, you can run multiple HiveQL statements one at a time, or package the HiveQL statement into a script file.
trans-unit.target: Using Azure PowerShell, you can run multiple HiveQL statements one at a time, or package the HiveQL statement into a script file.

trans-unit.source: This section shows you how to create a HiveQL script and upload the script to Azure Blob storage by using Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This section shows you how to create a HiveQL script and upload the script to Azure Blob storage by using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Hive requires the HiveQL scripts to be stored in Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: Hive requires the HiveQL scripts to be stored in Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: The HiveQL script will perform the following:
trans-unit.target: The HiveQL script will perform the following:

trans-unit.source: Drop the delays_raw table, in case the table already exists.
trans-unit.target: Drop the delays_raw table, in case the table already exists.

trans-unit.source: Create the delays_raw external Hive table pointing to the Blob storage location with the flight delay files.
trans-unit.target: Create the delays_raw external Hive table pointing to the Blob storage location with the flight delay files.

trans-unit.source: This query specifies that fields are delimited by "," and that lines are terminated by "\n".
trans-unit.target: This query specifies that fields are delimited by "," and that lines are terminated by "\n".

trans-unit.source: This poses a problem when field values contain commas because Hive cannot differentiate between a comma that is a field delimiter and a one that is part of a field value (which is the case in field values for ORIGIN\CITY\NAME and DEST\CITY\NAME).
trans-unit.target: This poses a problem when field values contain commas because Hive cannot differentiate between a comma that is a field delimiter and a one that is part of a field value (which is the case in field values for ORIGIN\CITY\NAME and DEST\CITY\NAME).

trans-unit.source: To address this, the query creates TEMP columns to hold data that is incorrectly split into columns.
trans-unit.target: To address this, the query creates TEMP columns to hold data that is incorrectly split into columns.

trans-unit.source: Drop the delays table, in case the table already exists.
trans-unit.target: Drop the delays table, in case the table already exists.

trans-unit.source: Create the delays table.
trans-unit.target: Create the delays table.

trans-unit.source: It is helpful to clean up the data before further processing.
trans-unit.target: It is helpful to clean up the data before further processing.

trans-unit.source: This query creates a new table, delays, from the delays_raw table.
trans-unit.target: This query creates a new table, delays, from the delays_raw table.

trans-unit.source: Note that the TEMP columns (as mentioned previously) are not copied, and that the substring function is used to remove quotation marks from the data.
trans-unit.target: Note that the TEMP columns (as mentioned previously) are not copied, and that the substring function is used to remove quotation marks from the data.

trans-unit.source: Compute the average weather delay and groups the results by city name. It will also output the results to Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: Compute the average weather delay and groups the results by city name. It will also output the results to Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: Note that the query will remove apostrophes from the data and will exclude rows where the value for weather_delay is null.
trans-unit.target: Note that the query will remove apostrophes from the data and will exclude rows where the value for weather_delay is null.

trans-unit.source: This is necessary because Sqoop, used later in this tutorial, doesn't handle those values gracefully by default.
trans-unit.target: This is necessary because Sqoop, used later in this tutorial, doesn't handle those values gracefully by default.

trans-unit.source: For a full list of the HiveQL commands, see <linkText>Hive Data Definition Language[hadoop-hiveql]</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a full list of the HiveQL commands, see <linkText>Hive Data Definition Language[hadoop-hiveql]</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Each HiveQL command must terminate with a semicolon.
trans-unit.target: Each HiveQL command must terminate with a semicolon.

trans-unit.source: To create a HiveQL script file
trans-unit.target: To create a HiveQL script file

trans-unit.source: Prepare the parameters:
trans-unit.target: Prepare the parameters:

trans-unit.source: Variable Name
trans-unit.target: Variable Name

trans-unit.source: Notes
trans-unit.target: Notes

trans-unit.source: $storageAccountName
trans-unit.target: $storageAccountName

trans-unit.source: The Azure Storage account where you want to upload the HiveQL script to.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Storage account where you want to upload the HiveQL script to.

trans-unit.source: $blobContainerName
trans-unit.target: $blobContainerName

trans-unit.source: The Blob container where you want to upload the HiveQL script to.
trans-unit.target: The Blob container where you want to upload the HiveQL script to.

trans-unit.source: Open Azure PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: Open Azure PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.source: Copy and paste the following script into the script pane:
trans-unit.target: Copy and paste the following script into the script pane:

trans-unit.source: Here are the variables used in the script:
trans-unit.target: Here are the variables used in the script:

trans-unit.source: $hqlLocalFileName - The script saves the HiveQL script file locally before uploading it to Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: $hqlLocalFileName - The script saves the HiveQL script file locally before uploading it to Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: This is the file name.
trans-unit.target: This is the file name.

trans-unit.source: The default value is <u>C:\tutorials\flightdelays\flightdelays.hql</u>.
trans-unit.target: The default value is <u>C:\tutorials\flightdelays\flightdelays.hql</u>.

trans-unit.source: $hqlBlobName - This is the HiveQL script file blob name used in the Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: $hqlBlobName - This is the HiveQL script file blob name used in the Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: The default value is tutorials/flightdelays/flightdelays.hql.
trans-unit.target: The default value is tutorials/flightdelays/flightdelays.hql.

trans-unit.source: Because the file will be written directly to Azure Blob storage, there is NOT a "/" at the beginning of the blob name.
trans-unit.target: Because the file will be written directly to Azure Blob storage, there is NOT a "/" at the beginning of the blob name.

trans-unit.source: If you want to access the file from Blob storage, you will need to add a "/" at the beginning of the file name.
trans-unit.target: If you want to access the file from Blob storage, you will need to add a "/" at the beginning of the file name.

trans-unit.source: $srcDataFolder and $dstDataFolder - = "tutorials/flightdelays/data" = "tutorials/flightdelays/output"
trans-unit.target: $srcDataFolder and $dstDataFolder - = "tutorials/flightdelays/data" = "tutorials/flightdelays/output"

trans-unit.source: To prepare the SQL database (merge this with the Sqoop script)
trans-unit.target: To prepare the SQL database (merge this with the Sqoop script)

trans-unit.source: Prepare the parameters:
trans-unit.target: Prepare the parameters:

trans-unit.source: Variable Name
trans-unit.target: Variable Name

trans-unit.source: Notes
trans-unit.target: Notes

trans-unit.source: $sqlDatabaseServerName
trans-unit.target: $sqlDatabaseServerName

trans-unit.source: The name of the Azure SQL database server. Enter nothing to create a new server.
trans-unit.target: The name of the Azure SQL database server. Enter nothing to create a new server.

trans-unit.source: $sqlDatabaseUsername
trans-unit.target: $sqlDatabaseUsername

trans-unit.source: The login name for the Azure SQL database server. If $sqlDatabaseServerName is an existing server, the login and login password are used to authenticate with the server. Otherwise they are used to create a new server.
trans-unit.target: The login name for the Azure SQL database server. If $sqlDatabaseServerName is an existing server, the login and login password are used to authenticate with the server. Otherwise they are used to create a new server.

trans-unit.source: $sqlDatabasePassword
trans-unit.target: $sqlDatabasePassword

trans-unit.source: The login password for the Azure SQL database server.
trans-unit.target: The login password for the Azure SQL database server.

trans-unit.source: $sqlDatabaseLocation
trans-unit.target: $sqlDatabaseLocation

trans-unit.source: This value is used only when you're creating a new Azure database server.
trans-unit.target: This value is used only when you're creating a new Azure database server.

trans-unit.source: $sqlDatabaseName
trans-unit.target: $sqlDatabaseName

trans-unit.source: The SQL database used to create the AvgDelays table for the Sqoop job. Leaving it blank will create a database called HDISqoop. The table name for the Sqoop job output is AvgDelays.
trans-unit.target: The SQL database used to create the AvgDelays table for the Sqoop job. Leaving it blank will create a database called HDISqoop. The table name for the Sqoop job output is AvgDelays.

trans-unit.source: Open Azure PowerShell ISE.
trans-unit.target: Open Azure PowerShell ISE.

trans-unit.source: Copy and paste the following script into the script pane:
trans-unit.target: Copy and paste the following script into the script pane:

trans-unit.source: The script uses a representational state transfer (REST) service, http://bot.whatismyipaddress.com, to retrieve your external IP address.
trans-unit.target: The script uses a representational state transfer (REST) service, http://bot.whatismyipaddress.com, to retrieve your external IP address.

trans-unit.source: The IP address is used for creating a firewall rule for your SQL database server.
trans-unit.target: The IP address is used for creating a firewall rule for your SQL database server.

trans-unit.source: Here are some variables used in the script:
trans-unit.target: Here are some variables used in the script:

trans-unit.source: $ipAddressRestService - The default value is http://bot.whatismyipaddress.com.
trans-unit.target: $ipAddressRestService - The default value is http://bot.whatismyipaddress.com.

trans-unit.source: It is a public IP address REST service for getting your external IP address.
trans-unit.target: It is a public IP address REST service for getting your external IP address.

trans-unit.source: You can use other services if you want.
trans-unit.target: You can use other services if you want.

trans-unit.source: The external IP address retrieved through the service will be used to create a firewall rule for your Azure SQL database server, so that you can access the database from your workstation (by using a Windows PowerShell script).
trans-unit.target: The external IP address retrieved through the service will be used to create a firewall rule for your Azure SQL database server, so that you can access the database from your workstation (by using a Windows PowerShell script).

trans-unit.source: $fireWallRuleName - This is the name of the firewall rule for the Azure SQL database server.
trans-unit.target: $fireWallRuleName - This is the name of the firewall rule for the Azure SQL database server.

trans-unit.source: The default name is <u>FlightDelay</u>.
trans-unit.target: The default name is <u>FlightDelay</u>.

trans-unit.source: You can rename it if you want.
trans-unit.target: You can rename it if you want.

trans-unit.source: $sqlDatabaseMaxSizeGB - This value is used only when you're creating a new Azure SQL database server.
trans-unit.target: $sqlDatabaseMaxSizeGB - This value is used only when you're creating a new Azure SQL database server.

trans-unit.source: The default value is 10GB.
trans-unit.target: The default value is 10GB.

trans-unit.source: 10GB is sufficient for this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: 10GB is sufficient for this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: $sqlDatabaseName - This value is used only when you're creating a new Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: $sqlDatabaseName - This value is used only when you're creating a new Azure SQL database.

trans-unit.source: The default value is HDISqoop.
trans-unit.target: The default value is HDISqoop.

trans-unit.source: If you rename it, you must update the Sqoop Windows PowerShell script accordingly.
trans-unit.target: If you rename it, you must update the Sqoop Windows PowerShell script accordingly.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 to run the script.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 to run the script.

trans-unit.source: Validate the script output.
trans-unit.target: Validate the script output.

trans-unit.source: Make sure the script ran successfully.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the script ran successfully.

trans-unit.source: Now you understand how to upload a file to Azure Blob storage, how to populate a Hive table by using the data from Azure Blob storage, how to run Hive queries, and how to use Sqoop to export data from HDFS to an Azure SQL database.
trans-unit.target: Now you understand how to upload a file to Azure Blob storage, how to populate a Hive table by using the data from Azure Blob storage, how to run Hive queries, and how to use Sqoop to export data from HDFS to an Azure SQL database.
